cab.content: Telegrams-"SHIPMINDER, VIC, LONDON.This Document is the PMperbj of Hjs Britannic lt;aJosty'3 GovernmentAny further communicatdon on this subject should bo addressed to Tho Secretary,Ministry of Shipping,St. Jamcs's Park.London, S.W. 1,and the following number quoted:-1MINISTRY OF SHIPPING, 10th June, 1918.1%JL *2.In continuation of my letter of the 3rd instant, I am directed by the Shipping Controller to report, for the information of the War Cabinet, as follows CONVOYS.*(a) Homeward bound Convoys. Since the last report 11 convoys, consisting of 149 ships (1,046,800 tons deadweight) have arrived. There was one casualty by enemy action. The s/s "WANETA" was torpedoed and sunk on the 30th May while under escort from Queenstown, after being detached from the convoy. There were no casualties due to marine peril. There are now on passage home 21 convoys consisting of 331 ships,(b) Outward bound Convoys. Since the last report 10 convoys consisting of 130 ships (938,400 tons deadweight) have been escorted through the danger zone. There were no casualties of any description. There are now on passage home 5 convoys, consisting of 75 ships.FINANCE.During the week ended the 1st June the sum of 1,544,402 was paid in compensation for loss of requisitioned ships, making a total of 10,941,010 paid on this account since the 1st April, 1918.THE SECRETARY, WAR CABINET. LOSSES AND GAINS OF BRITISH TONNAGE.The losses of British steamers of 500 gross tons and upwards during the week ended the 25th May were as follows :-Lost by enemy action : - 14 ships of 51,559 gross tons. Lost by marine peril 1 ship of 1,455 " "making a total of 15 ships of 53,014 gross tons.The gains during the week were as follows New vessels (British built) brought into service : -25 ships of 131,588 gross tons. New vessels purchased overseas :-1 ship of 2,053 gross tons.Total 26 ships of 133,641 gross tons.making a net gain of 11 ships of 80,627 gross tons.There were also transferred from the Norwegian flag 2 ships of 4,311 tons which were already running in Allied Service, COAL POSITION.The settlement of the strike in South Wales has afforded some relief, but coal for export is still coming forward very slowly. This week and next the supply of steam coal particularly Is quite inadequate, and the necessity arises of compelling ships to take cargoes of inferior coals and even these are only obtainable after considerable delay to tonnage.Meetings have been held, between the Ministry of Shipping and the Board of Trade, and a report is being prepared for Lord Robert Cecil, to enable him to consider the question, and if necessary to submit to the War Cabinet recommendations as to the steps to be taken to ensure a sufficient quantity of coal being made available to meet the British Government^ various obligations to Allies and Neutrals, NEW GOVERNMENT TONNAGE.The following standard ships have been delivered s-"WAR JACKDAW"/ "WAR JACKDAW""WAR AFRICAN""WAR MANOR"WAR BATTERY""WAR BUCKLER""WAR VISOR""WAR PERCH""WAR LEMUR""WAR STAG"WAR BISON1!"WAR PANTHER"The following ships built in Canada have been delivered ?-"WAR ISIS" and "WAR DANCE". EX-FOREIGN SHIPS LOST,The 3/s "SKARAAS" (requisitioned Norwegian) and "POLWELL" (Prize) have been lost through enemy action, andthe s/b "PHYLLIS", requisitioned Norwegian, has been lostthrough marine loss*REMOUNTS FROM AMERICA TO AUSTRALIA.to India, and to increase the shipment of remounts from the United States.STORES TOR THE BRITISH ARMY IN FRANCE.In the week ending 1st instant, 182,784 tons of Military Stores were discharged in France.I am,Sir,Your obedient Servant,It has been arranged to provide tonnage for the conveyance of a considerable number of horses from Australia(Sgd.) John Anderson.
